author: neielv
title: "MINING" educative board game
description: Despite all the blockchain education initiatives, there are no mechanisms to bring this knowledge to people with no technical backgrounds.

f6_assessments.q0: I don't understand the basis for the game, titled "Mining" as a promoter of Cardano, a PoS blockchain which does not depend on mining the way that PoW blockchains do.  I like the idea of a childrens board game, but I do not think the idea is developed enough to be impactful, since the idea seems to lack a clear understanding of the blockchain.  Recommending to the author to develop a team of technical experts to collaborate on a future proposal that helps articulate the themes and style of the game in a more digestible format.
f6_assessments.q1: I know from friends in the board gaming industry that game design and development is a complex and detail oriented field.  The proposal features no details about the plan for the game, other than a mockup of the box along with imagery of dice and cards, and a name which is seemingly irrelevant to the Cardano blockchain.
f6_assessments.q2: The author offers metrics for measuring auditability, but those are purely designs and quantities of people who tested the game.  Had the proposal included a full plan for commercialization, marketing, and distribution, the implementation success could have instead been measured by units sold or distributed.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is presenting an idea of developing a POC for a board game to introduce blockchain mechanisms for people with no prior technical background. In terms of challenge alignment, this proposal is submitted in the correct challenge. It could be questioned if this proposal would be more suitable in the "Gamers on-chained" challenge, but that challenge aligns more towards digital games and content. 
The proposer explains that the game will teach basic concepts of blockchains in general, but there is no clear connection to the Cardano community presented. A suggestion is to clarify in the proposal if there is a stronger connection to the Cardano community other than it being one of many blockchains.

This proposal does not aim to go further than a playable POC but the finished product is a physical set, which limits the availability by a lot. In order to make the board game available there is a big workload related to production and marketing that is necessary to bring the POC to a finished product on the market. Reflections regarding this matter would be useful for a reader but it will not affect the score since the proposals is clearly aiming for a POC only.
All in all the proposal is somewhat impactful and aligned with the challenge setting, the score will be neutral - 3 stars awarded in terms of impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer claims to be knowledgeable and experience in the blockchain domain, there are no further evidence to back up these claims but given the scope of the proposal it is deemed sufficient enough. 
The POC has been developed incrementally to a degree, this is a crucial process in development and raises the feasibility of the proposal. Milestones/stages has been laid out with key components of the development, it is somewhat sparse but still reasonable. The same goes for the budget. Since the proposer has already started the initial development, these estimates seem more credible as well. 
A question to raise is the proposers experience with hiring designers and illustrators, with a limited budget it might pose to be somewhat of a challenge to find the right people. 
This proposal is deemed feasible given the scope, but one point is deducted from the score because it provides very general milestones/stages and there are uncertainties regarding the external actors that has to be hired. Score given: 4 stars.
f6_assessments.q2:
The metrics used to measure progress are clear, measurable and relevant for a POC of this scope. It could be expanded upon how this would be communicated to the community and where the progress could be followed. An example could be to provide a blog, discord channel or anything alike. 
Success is defined as a finalized POC with the game mechanisms developed, given the scope and simplicity of the POC this seems like a reasonable goal, it is sufficient and enough. 
In terms of auditability the proposal is rated 4 stars, in order to achieve 5 stars in the future, the proposal should state expand upon how the progress can be audited during the development.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer wishes to create a physical board game that encourages more people to learn about blockchain technology. This could indeed help bring awareness to the technology and the Cardano ecosystem to people outside the typical crypto community. I do, however, wonder if the proposal could be more impactful if the game was digital, allowing for a larger customer base and global reach. To receive a higher rating I would recommend the proposer to further describe how the game works and how it will encourage users to further engage with blockchain technology.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has a clear plan for how he wishes to develop the game, and has already provided proof of concept as he has developed an initial design and tested the game play on users. This strengthens the credibility and feasibility of the project as the proposer has gained understanding of the process needed to complete the game. While the proposer provides a good budget breakdown, he does not address the cost of marketing and distribution. Costs that oftentimes are quite high when launching a new product to market.In order to achieve a higher rating the proposer should discuss how he plans to gain consumer interest in the product and the distribution model needed to produce, store and ship the products to customers. All in all, the cost and logistics of marketing and distribution of a physical product makes it less feasible to complete the project within the time and cost limits given.
f6_assessments.q2: While the proposer states a few milestones that describe the progress of the project, the audibility ends when a finished proof of concept is complete and the game is developed. The proposer does not discuss how he wishes to ensure auditability of the continued operations and sales of the board game. To receive a higher rating I recommend the proposer to address this issue and include measurable KPIs that allows the Carando community to audit the return of their investment in the long run. This could for example. be  # of games sold, revenue goals, customer satisfaction etc.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposer wants to develop a board game “that uses traditional elements such as dice, an hourglass, a board and puzzle cards” with the aim to educate the players about blockchain. 
However, the game is titled “Mining Educational Game” and the only detail about blockchain technology that is described is proof of work, which raises the question if the proposer is knowledgeable about how Cardano functions or why he has omitted it from the proposal text.
Otherwise, the proposer mentions “I believe one of the main objectives of the Challenge is to onboard new members into the world of blockchain and Cardano”, which is not accurate at all, the Miscellaneous challenge has the purpose to accommodate proposals that are not fit in any other challenge, and for the purpose of this proposal, there is another challenge named “Gamers On - Chained” with the main goal of “What Blockchain gaming applications should be developed to achieve mass adoption of Cardano?”
As such, I recommend resubmission in a future fund in a more appropriate challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
Having some experience with game design, I know that the most important aspect of the success of a game is game mechanics or, how the game is played. If it is fun, it will be played, no matter the design quality, if it’s not fun, it doesn’t matter how good it will look.
I’m saying this, because the proposer has not described this step in the detailed plan and timeline, nor has he accounted for it in the budget or team description.
The proposer seems to be a novice in this field, and while I can see the good intentions and consider the idea behind the project valuable, I would really recommend him to find someone with experience, at least as a consultant in this project and before setting up to work on it, to look at some introductions to game design, as a valuable resource for novices, is Brenda Romero's short tutorials, available also on LinkedIn (there is a free trial of one month).
Otherwise, the budget is not sufficiently broken-down, it is not clear how the sums have been calculated, as there are no number of hours provided and cost per hour.
The proposer has not provided any kind of skill description, previous works or links to verify his ability to implement the project.
f6_assessments.q2:
The progress measurement is sufficiently well described, it would have been important to also mention where the reports will be made available, but I haven’t removed any points for that.
The success description is too general, it’s important to provide well defined milestones, that would enable the community in verifying the success and progress of the project.

f6_assessments.q0: From the perspective of a person who has worked in creative education and social innovation since 2010, this proposal gives me a lot of inspiration regarding educating children and young adult (and possibly adults too) not only about Cardano and block chain, but also about coding, technology, the future world, etc. Imagine if we can educate children on the many basics of block chain and utilize their creativity, curiousity, and unconventional/ unbiased thinking in generating new ideas for the Cardano community or incubating their own inventions in the future. This simple solution can both add much values to our Cardano ecosystem and scale either independently or interconnectedly in the future.
f6_assessments.q1:
Despite believing or being inspired by the solution, I am a bit skeptical on its feasibility because of three things: 


1. Gamification is never easy, and personally I think requires a knack and wit for making interesting games and intriguing mechanisms. I have not seen this demonstrated from the proposer's profile, existing/tested mechanism, plan to acquire new members, or plan to learn it from the players. I would suggest the proposer to demonstrate this more clearly in his proposal next time, and showcase more of the current designs, tested mechanisms, surprises and insights from rounds of testing. 

2. Despite iteration is mentioned, the implementation stages have not yet reflected this nature. Currently, it looks like a design and production timeline, rather than a mechanism testing and building process. I would suggest the proposer to focus more on testing and break down the testing process into more step-by-step modules e.g. building an initial testing community (e.g. a group of passionate friends/first adopters), interviewing learners of block chain from different stages to understand what do they appreciate learning about block chain at each stages, making infildelity prototypes (with pen and paper) to test gaming mechanisms with the groups, making initial designs and prints to test mood and feelings, etc.

3. Bringing physical products to life does not stop at initiating or testing it, but also in bringing it to the community or into the market. I would love to see an initial sketch on this matter. Is it a creative common for everyone else to develop further, or a physical card product that need to work with a publisher to publish and distribute, or else? 

	
Having said that, I think the budget is quire reasonable if the USD 2000 budget for x4 trials is distributed down to many more cheaper rounds of testing, and to a commited groups of block chain advocates. With that perspective, I think the timeline is quite rush, and final designs and production should be delayed until the end of the testing proces.
f6_assessments.q2: I understand from the proposal that the deliverable in Fund 8 would be a prototype. However, it's hard to deduce what does success mean for this period, what are the criterias for a successful prototypes (or to be more specific, a successful gaming and learning mechanism), how to incorporate these criterias into the developing and evaluating proces, etc. When I mentioned criterias, I mean learning outcomes, element of fun, intensity, feelings, time commited for each round of game, age groups specifics, desires to play the next game, etc. Meanwhile, the proposer is using quantitative factors to demonstrate efforts (outputs), rather than using qualitative factors to demonstrate succes (outcomes). Therefore, without a clear criteria for success, it's hard to establish its clarity and auditability.

solution: Create a boardgame that teaches basic concepts of blockchain in a didactic and fun way without the need for technical jargon.
